subs.text: June 24

subs.text: I took a photo of a book someone standing next to me was reading (I got permission to) thinking I’d look it up later. I took 180 photos since then. At the time, what would have been a good way to be reminded of that specific photo a short time after taking it?

subs.text: Halfway through the year, and I’m well on my way to listening to more music than I did in 2007. Buying good wireless headphones in April had a lot to do with that. [link]

subs.text: For a while I was listening to albums… [link]
subs.rawText: For a while I was listening to albums… https://t.co/R8JCwVCfEi

subs.text: …and then I started to listen to an artist’s entire discography, in chronological order if possible (sometimes all of their albums aren’t online, or I can’t wait to listen to a certain album)…
subs.rawText: …and then I started to listen to an artist’s entire discography, in chronological order if possible (sometimes all of their albums aren’t online, or I can’t wait to listen to a certain album)…

subs.text: …and now I’m more and more listening to playlists, usually shuffled.

subs.text: A reminder for audience members asking questions of a speaker: “I don’t need a mic” might be something you truly believe, but you don’t know who needs you to use a mic so that they can hear you.
subs.rawText: A reminder for audience members asking questions of a speaker: “I don’t need a mic” might be something you truly believe, but you don’t know who needs you to use a mic so that they can hear you.

subs.text: If the session is being recorded and you didn’t say your more-of-a-comment-than-a-question into a microphone, it probably didn’t get captured.
subs.rawText: If the session is being recorded and you didn’t say your more-of-a-comment-than-a-question into a microphone, it probably didn’t get captured.

subs.text: @nealjennings Hiiii, and bye. I’m on my way back to Toronto. Sort of too bad we didn’t meet up, but it wouldn’t have worked out on this trip. Family visits take up all my social bandwidth. Not a complaint, just a thing. Next time we’re in the same town again, let’s try to meet up!

subs.text: Who do I know, or who knows me, that’ll be in Toronto for #CollisionConf next week? I’ll be in town too!

subs.text: #CollisionConf attendees: Put your phone on silent when you fly into Toronto. It’s illegal to have sound notifications turned on in an airplane in Canada. The fine is $50 for the first one, then the previous fine plus $25 (so, $75, then $100) for each successive occurrence.
subs.rawText: #CollisionConf attendees: Put your phone on silent when you fly into Toronto. It’s illegal to have sound notifications turned on in an airplane in Canada. The fine is $50 for the first one, then the previous fine plus $25 (so, $75, then $100) for each successive occurrence.

subs.text: #CollisionConf attendees: For a great breakfast, with outdoor seating, the best diner in Toronto is Avenue Open Kitchen at 7 Camden St. It’s open At 7 AM every weekday. Tell them Richard sent you! Hell, I might even join you.
subs.rawText: #CollisionConf attendees: For a great breakfast, with outdoor seating, the best diner in Toronto is Avenue Open Kitchen at 7 Camden St. It’s open At 7 AM every weekday. Tell them Richard sent you! Hell, I might even join you.

subs.text: Unfortunately, I couldn’t get my forthcoming book, Toronto: The Good Parts, published in time for #CollisionConf. In the meantime, start here for a thread on what to see in Canada’s largest, and therefore best, city. [link]
subs.rawText: Unfortunately, I couldn’t get my forthcoming book, Toronto: The Good Parts, published in time for #CollisionConf. In the meantime, start here for a thread on what to see in Canada’s largest, and therefore best, city. https://t.co/NtYlXDvCsb

subs.text: The second-best way to see Toronto is with a weekly TTC pass, assuming you can figure out how to buy one. The best way to see Toronto is by bike. Just ask Arnold! #CollisionConf (He’s not riding one, but @BikeShareTO is cheap and plentiful.) [link]
subs.rawText:
The second-best way to see Toronto is with a weekly TTC pass, assuming you can figure out how to buy one.

The best way to see Toronto is by bike. Just ask Arnold! #CollisionConf

(He’s not riding one, but @BikeShareTO is cheap and plentiful.) https://t.co/GPG3P8CS2p

subs.rawText: Security at D gates was a breeze. I’m still good with arriving 3 hours early (and not the recommended 2). I’m glad I held myself back from arriving 4 hours early.

subs.text: An hour delay,with the plane stuck at the gate. It’s hard to get mad when there’s so much to do (read a book, watch a movie, try to catch the eye of the ground crew and wave at them).
subs.rawText: An hour delay,with the plane stuck at the gate. It’s hard to get mad when there’s so much to do (read a book, watch a movie, try to catch the eye of the ground crew and wave at them).

subs.text: I’m in the air now. Long flights are where I try to make a decision or two, deciding being the thing I hate doing the most.
subs.rawText: I’m in the air now. Long flights are where I try to make a decision or two, deciding being the thing I hate doing the most.

subs.text: I decided a bunch of small things on the flight, mostly consisting of changing “write/think about” to “do one thing towards” in my repeating reminders. Something something cabin pressure makes you think if not better, then at least differently something something.

subs.text:
Posit: People think the economy might be shaky, leading to a recession.
Consequence: People start to reduce their spending.
Result: Pretty soon the economy *is* shaky, leading to a recession.
Conclusion: You can cause an economy to be shaky, leading to a recession.
subs.rawText:
Posit: People think the economy might be shaky, leading to a recession.

subs.rawText: I need to tell an interviewer for an internal talk show at work a little fun fact or something I’d like to share with people that they may not know about me. Something interesting that I’m not embarrassed about, obviously. What should I tell the interviewer?

subs.text: I won a search engine contest in 2004. Is that interesting? I wanted to prove that having a blog was good for SEO. To encourage people to link to me, and so that some good could come of it, I promised I’d make a donation to charity if I won, a promise I kept.
subs.rawText: I won a search engine contest in 2004. Is that interesting? I wanted to prove that having a blog was good for SEO. To encourage people to link to me, and so that some good could come of it, I promised I’d make a donation to charity if I won, a promise I kept.

subs.text: Winning the search engine contest feels like of the few thing I set out to do, felt sure I could get done, and was right, and that was a long time ago. Everything else I can think of fell into my lap and all I had to do was say Yes.
subs.rawText: Winning the search engine contest feels like of the few thing I set out to do, felt sure I could get done, and was right, and that was a long time ago. Everything else I can think of fell into my lap and all I had to do was say Yes.

subs.text: I’m leaning towards requesting that the interviewer not ask the question.
subs.rawText: I’m leaning towards requesting that the interviewer not ask the question.

subs.text: Here’s the blog post that won me the search engine contest in 2004. Note that all the links are broken, so uh, don’t click them. [link]
subs.rawText: Here’s the blog post that won me the search engine contest in 2004. Note that all the links are broken, so uh, don’t click them. https://t.co/k4BV4wRb1Z

subs.text: If you’re in Ontario and you need to get something off your chest without anybody noticing, tonight might be a good time to do it.

subs.text: I voted. [link]
subs.rawText: I voted. https://t.co/COtVExZeUi

subs.text: The Hyatt Regency Hotel on King St. W. does not allow directional signs in the lobby for where specifically I was to cast my ballot, apparently. I had to ask an attendant if I was at the right place. I made my voice heard to the elections workers. They felt their hands were tied.

subs.text: @Kimli It’s usually a bad idea to declare that you haven’t done something, because you only have done it once for it to be a lie, and even so, declaring that you didn’t do something makes people suspect you indeed did it.

subs.text: What are the predictions as to when there will be projections for the results of the Ontario election? Is there a place to bet on when projections will come from the various media entities? Is politics betting legal in Ontario? #onelxn #onpoli #ontariovotes #ontarioelection2022
subs.rawText: What are the predictions as to when there will be projections for the results of the Ontario election? Is there a place to bet on when projections will come from the various media entities? Is politics betting legal in Ontario? #onelxn #onpoli #ontariovotes #ontarioelection2022

subs.text: I had 9:17 PM as the time I bet that the first major media entity would project a majority government.
subs.rawText: I had 9:17 PM as the time I bet that the first major media entity would project a majority government.

subs.text: It’s over now. You don’t have to watch any of the election coverage any more. All the speeches will be on YouTube tomorrow. If it’s not your job to cover the election, you can literally do anything else if you so choose.
subs.rawText: It’s over now. You don’t have to watch any of the election coverage any more. All the speeches will be on YouTube tomorrow. If it’s not your job to cover the election, you can literally do anything else if you so choose.

subs.text: To get ahead of the story, I will not accept the nomination as leader of the Ontario NDP, and will not serve if elected.
subs.rawText: To get ahead of the story, I will not accept the nomination as leader of the Ontario NDP, and will not serve if elected.

subs.text: @leppert This is sad news, but I knew this day would come. Any chance of open-sourcing the software behind it? I know that everything requires maintenance, and even considered asking to take it over, until I realized I hadn't considered how much effort it might take.
subs.rawText: @leppert This is sad news, but I knew this day would come. Any chance of open-sourcing the software behind it? I know that everything requires maintenance, and even considered asking to take it over, until I realized I hadn't considered how much effort it might take.

subs.text: This is sad news. Reading is one of my favourite web apps of all time. I will still post to @sglisreading, though with my cobbled-together solution of Pinboard, RSS, and Huggin, taped together with love. [link]
subs.rawText: This is sad news. Reading is one of my favourite web apps of all time. I will still post to @sglisreading, though with my cobbled-together solution of Pinboard, RSS, and Huggin, taped together with love. https://t.co/UmYtXr2cPI

subs.text:
Reading was magical because:

1. You could tell who read something because of you.
2. You could see who was reading something from individual domains.
3. You could “Yep” (heartily suggest something) or “Nope” (recommend against something), and it had hooks for each.
subs.rawText:
Reading was magical because:

1. You could tell who read something because of you.
2. You could see who was reading something from individual domains.
3. You could “Yep” (heartily suggest something) or “Nope” (recommend against something), and it had hooks for each.

subs.text: Happy Jubilee! We in Canada are celebrating by *not* having a day off from work and *not* having a parade, even though Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II has ruled over our country with just as firm an iron fist and for just as long as she has over her other realms.
